"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress recognizes the significance of the 1954 Brown v. Board of Education decision and the integration of the "Little Rock Nine" students at Central High School as a catalyst for desegregation in public schools. The integration of the "Little Rock Nine" at Central High School was a prominent national example of implementing the Brown decision, leading to the integration of other public schools. Central High School, recognized for its beauty, was included on the National Register of Historic Places in 1977. (3) In 1997, Central High School celebrated its 70th anniversary and was recognized as the most beautiful high school building in America by the American Institute of Architects. Central High School was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1977 and designated a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement. The school's designation as a unit of the National Park System will acknowledge its significance. The Little Rock Central High School was designated as a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement and the desegregation of public schools in the South. The purpose of this Act is to preserve, protect, and interpret the school's significance for present and future generations. The Act aims to preserve and interpret Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, for future generations, highlighting its role in the integration of public schools and the civil rights movement in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as a unit of the National Park System in Arkansas. The site includes the Central High School campus and will be administered by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the Little Rock Central High School historic site in accordance with relevant laws. The Little Rock School District retains authority over the school. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the Little Rock Central High School historic site in accordance with relevant laws, including cooperative agreements with public and private agencies. The Little Rock School District retains authority over the school. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies for the management of Central High School. Coordination with the Little Rock School District and Central High School Museum is required for visitor interpretation. A general management plan must be prepared within 2 years of funds availability. The Secretary will coordinate visitor interpretation of the historic site with the Little Rock School District and Central High School Museum. Within 2 years, a general management plan for the historic site must be prepared. The Secretary will consult with the Little Rock School District to ensure the historic site does not interfere with Central High School's educational use. The Secretary will consult and coordinate with the Little Rock School District in developing the general management plan for the historic site. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the site with the owner's consent. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the historic site by purchase, exchange, or donation with consent of the owner, excluding lands owned by the State of Arkansas or a political subdivision, which can only be acquired by donation or exchange. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation in public education. The theme study on the history of desegregation in public education will identify sites that best illustrate key events in the movement for racial desegregation. The Secretary will also identify new national historic landmarks related to this theme and establish linkages between sites for education and research. The theme study will identify new national historic landmarks related to desegregation in public education and establish linkages between sites for education and research. Opportunities for cooperative arrangements with State and local entities will also be recommended. The High School National Historic Site was established to promote public education and research on desegregation in public education. The theme study recommends cooperative arrangements with various entities to preserve and interpret key sites in this history. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with major educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations to prepare the theme study on desegregation in public education. The theme study will be part of the general management plan for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. The theme study on desegregation in public education for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site will be prepared in coordination with the general management plan. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums may be appropriated as necessary for this Act.
